definition: to put oneself in sb else's shoes (idiom)
will/shall/to use/to take/to checkmate/just a short while ago/(introduces object of main verb, used in the same way as 把[ba3])
Belgium/Belgian/abbr. for 比利時|比利时[Bi3 li4 shi2]
to compare/(followed by a noun and adjective) more {adj.} than {noun}/ratio/to gesture/(Taiwan pr. [bi4] in some compounds derived from Classical Chinese)

sentences.english: Caring about the customers concern and feeling.
sentences.chinese: 將心比心，關注客戶的利益和感受。

sentences.english: You should feel for others. Don't be too harsh.
sentences.chinese: 你應當將心比心，別太苛刻了。

sentences.english: Thank them and send compliments their way.
sentences.chinese: 將心比心地感謝他們，讚美他們。

sentences.english: By putting yourself in her shoes, you will understand her feeling.
sentences.chinese: 將心比心，你就能瞭解她的心情。

definition: to satisfy rival demands (idiom)/to get the best of both worlds/to have it both ways/to have one's cake and eat it too
to resign oneself to adversity (idiom); to grin and bear it/to submit meekly to insults, maltreatment, humiliation etc
to move aside/to get out of the way/to back down/to concede
to think highly of oneself (idiom); giving oneself airs/arrogant and self-important
to argue/to reason with sb/to talk sense/to be reasonable
lit. look into one's heart, no shame (idiom); with a clear conscience
to empathize/to allow (for sth)/to show understanding/to appreciate
to put oneself in sb else's shoes
